string.text: Źmiescavany liedź nižej pa race ad źlićcia rekaŭ Avier i Lammier, horad Štrajsien viadomy svaim revaliucyjnym ducham i pieramienlivym minulym. U horadzie znachodzicca nievialiki ŭniviersitet i miedyčnaja škola, sumna viadomaja tym, što vypuskaje vučniaŭ, jakija nie prytrymvajucca starych šliachoŭ. Niekali Štrajsien mieŭ svaju ŭlasnuju haradskuju chartyju, što davala šmat paliohak i mahčymasć abirać svaich kiraŭnikoŭ, alie jana byla skasavana ŭ vyniku ŭhody z Hrafiniaj Liudmilaj Aĺptraŭm, jakaja vyratavala horad ad revaliucyi pad čalom studentaŭ. Univiersitet praciahvaje funkcyjavać, alie ŭspaminy pra čystki paślia hvaltoŭnaha pryhniečańnia Aĺptraŭmam dahetuĺ śviežyja ŭ pamiaci boĺšaści žycharoŭ. Tut pracuje pieraprava, jakaja zabiaśpiečvaje puć praz Avier.

Lienhienfeĺd zjaŭliajecca asnoŭnaj volaściu Hrafini Karmilly fon Zaks. Tutejšyja dlia pražytka loviać rybu ŭ race Avier. Sušać i pradajuć jaje razam sa svajoj žyviolaj, kab nažyć bahaćcie. Taksama tutaka znachodzicca pieraprava, jakaja paliahčaje ruch i handaĺ praz raku Avier dy źbiraje padatki dlia svajho šliachciča.

Na zachodniaj miažy Liesu Plaču znachodzicca vioska Bisvanh. Liudzi tut vyžyvajuć za košt taho, što mohuć vyhadavać, i handliujuć, kab nabyć toje, što nia mohuć vyrabić. U adroźnieńnie ad boĺšaści avierliandaŭ, ich blizkasć da nibyta prakliataha liesu zrabila ich zababonnymi; čužyncam ciažka zaslužyć ich davier.

Źmiescavany na skryžavańni darohaŭ Staryja Šliachi Hnomaŭ, horad Chajdek byŭ spradviečna pabudavany hnomami ŭ časy roskvitu ichniaha haspadarstva niekaĺki tysiačahodździaŭ tamu. Malalikija zachavanyja pabudovy hnomaŭ dahetuĺ vykarystoŭvajucca liudźmi, i zjaŭliajucca žyvym śviedčańniem architekturnych standartaŭ starejšaj rasy. Pa čutkach, pad Chajdekam znachodzicca mnostva katakombaŭ hnomaŭ, napoŭnienych staražytnymi skarbami i artefaktami, jakija toĺki i čakajuć, kab ich znajšli i zabrali.

U atačeńni rova i kamiennaha častakolu znachodzicca horad Koĺmfahr. Heta ściply horad. Horadam i jaho navakoĺliem kiruje Baron Zihmund Hindenbierh, jaki piĺnuje za ŭsim z Zamka Hindenburh, źmiescavanaha na susiednim uzhorku. Pieraprava absluhoŭvaje padarožnikaŭ, jakija žadajuć pierasiekčy raku Rajk, jakaja ci ciače na poŭdzień, ci na poŭnač u Averliand.

Zjaŭliajučysia nievialikim horadam u paŭdniovaj častcy Averlianda, Loninhbruk služyć najvažniejšym prypynkam dlia handliaroŭ, što vandrujuć pa race Rajk, abo ŭniz pa race da Maryjenburha i Vialikaha Akijana, abo ŭharu pa race da Haspadarstvaŭ Hnomaŭ. Taksama heta adzin z malalikich šliachoŭ, što viadzie da Pieravalu Čornaje Polymia i prachodzić praz Loninhbruk. U vyniku hetych mierkantyĺnych intaresaŭ ekanomika horada zaliežyć ad handliu, jaki zabiaśpiečvajuć hetyja maršruty. Aproč taho, horad toĺki prodaje žyviolu. U horadzie daminujuć vialiki zajezny dom Skryžavanyja Kliučy i chram Viareny, samy vialiki chram u horadzie. Loninhbruk, na žaĺ, taksama nosić imia Loninhbruk Rubinavy, bo sumna viadomy nizkajakasnym vinom.

Radzima Baranesy Aĺdar, niepieraborlivaja vioska Biernloch najboliej viadomaja svaim Biernloskim Ćviordym Syram. Žychary vioski haloŭnym čynam razvodziać kozaŭ dzielia miasa, syru dy handliu na darozie miž Ahbajtienam i Chajdekam.

Doki ŭ Chochšliben paznačajuć kaniec Vierchniaha Rajka dlia ruchu karablioŭ. Chacia raka praciahvajecca vyšej u hory na šmatlikija mili, paślia hetaha miesca parohi, vadaspady i ŭźnimańni robiacca zanadta niebiaśpiečnymi dlia padarožžaŭ. U vyniku ŭ horadzie zvyčajna źbirajecca mnostva lodak i karablioŭ, jakija handliujuć tavarami, što iduć ci prychodziać z Horaŭ Rohu Śvietu.

Ahbajtien - heta vialikaja vioska, jakaja služyć jak handliovym, hetak i relihijnym centram u Paŭdniovym Averliandzie. Talibenplac, centar Ahbajtiena, - heta vialiki pliac, na jakim Ahbajtien pravodzić svoj štodzionny kirmaš, źmiescavany na skryžavańni šliachoŭ Loninhbruka, Chochšlibena i Chajdeka. Na paŭnočnym kancy pliacu znachodziacca chramy Zihmara, Uĺryka i Viareny. Kruhly, pabudavany z dreva chram Taalia i Rai - adzin z najbujniejšych u Paŭdniovaj Impieryi i adzin z malalikich, źmiescavanych u kamiennych ścienach horada. Žychary Ahbajtiena haloŭnym čynam zjaŭliajucca paśliadoŭnikami Taalia i Rai.

Malieńkaja vioska Zeĺ byla zasnavana na adnym z silkavaĺnych prytokaŭ Blakitnaj Miažy. Chacia vada tut zanadta plytkaja dlia vialikich handliovych karablioŭ, zvyčajnych dlia inšych rek, viaskoŭcy ŭžyvajuć nievialikija čoŭny i plyty dlia pieravozki ŭradžaju ŭ Faĺlienblat, dzie jaho ĺha pradać Paŭroślikam ci pieravieźci daliej uniz pa race.

Dzitfurc dastaŭliaje ziernie ŭ navakoĺnyja sieliščy, a taksama ŭ kramy Funcyha. Tutejšyja žychary z padozram staviacca da pryjezdžych, aścierahajučysia, što jany špijony paŭroślikaŭ ci jašče horš; vandroŭniki z uschodniaha Šcirlianda. Hraf fon Hajn najmaje mnohich svaich žaŭnioraŭ u Dzitfurcy, šmatlikija ź ich viartajucca dadomu, kali vychodziać na piensiju, u vyniku z mužčynaŭ Dzitfurca atrymvajucca vydatnyja vajary.

Bibierchof liažyć u atačeńni hustoha liesu ŭ niekaĺkich kilamietrach da poŭdnia ad Vurtbada. Jaho žychary pa-majstersku vykarystoŭvajuć siakiery, jak dlia narychtoŭki vysakajakasnaj draŭniny sa starych drevaŭ vakol, hetak i dlia abarony svaich lahieraŭ ad škodnikaŭ i vypadkovych razbojnikaŭ. Draŭnina z Bidierchofa karystajecca popytam u šliachty Vurtbada, pakoĺki havorać, što jaje ciomnaje adcieńnie prakliata dlia ŭsiakaha vampira, jakomu nie paščaścila być prakolatym hetym drevam.

Juĺbach raźmieščany na paŭdarozie miž Rekami Šcir i Avier. Jon raźmieščany ŭ dalinie, zacienienaj Uzhorkami Zaja, dzie ŭzdoŭž Darohi Nuĺn voĺna švendajucca aviečki. Lies Nattarn, źmiescavany ŭ niekaĺkich miliach da zachadu, služyć adnačasna krynicaj bahaćcia i zababonaŭ, pakoĺki navat u samyja chalodnyja zimovyja nočy, kali i nasiakomyja, i źviary śpiać, udaliečyni čutny hruk kapytoŭ.

Vobierviĺ - nievialikaja rybackaja vioska ŭ niekaĺkich miliach da zachadu ad Vurtbada. Šliachi ŭ Vobierviĺ - nia boĺš za piešachodnyja ściežki, pakoĺki vialikaja častka handliu i padarožžaŭ ažyćciaŭliajecca pa race. Vioska ŭ peŭnaj stupieni abaroniena Račnymi Nahliadnikami, jakija časta naviedvajuć Šcir, alie ŭ celym žycharam davodzicca samim dužacca z bandytami i źvieraliudźmi z ciomnaha liesu.

Tarschof raźmieščany na paŭnočnaj uskrainie Ŭzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhieĺ. Vioska karystajecca vialikim popytam u handliaroŭ, jakija vandrujuć miž Vurtbadam i Viordenam pa Starym Šliachu Hnomaŭ. U vyniku, amaĺ kožnaja chata ŭ vioscy pretenduje na zvańnie karčmy, choć haścinnasć vieĺmi adroźnivajecca, i vandroŭniki mohuć apynucca na kučy siena, a nie na narmaĺnym ložku.

Fliensburh malieńki kirmašovy horad, jaki mieścicca lia Ŭzhorkaŭ Zaja na zachadzie ad Šcirchuhielia. Uzhorki ideaĺna padychodziać dlia pašy aviečak, a ekanomika horada zasnavana na vytvorčaści poŭści, baraniny i jahniaciny. Horad taksama viadomy ŭ kraje tym, što ŭ im znachodzicca bujny chram Šaĺli.

Lochien zjaŭliajecca daččynym sieliščam susiedniaha horada Fliensburh. U vioski haloŭnym čynam žyvuć ziemliaroby, jakija zabiaśpiečvajuć horad zierniem. Lochien znachodzicca pad abaronaj Hrafini Pietry Charden i jaje vajaroŭ.

Francen - nia varty ŭvahi horad, źmiescavany ŭ cieni bujnych sieliščaŭ pablizu. Jon viadzie aktyŭnuju rybnuju loŭliu ŭ Lammiery i Aviery, a taksama moža pachvalicca duža karystanaj pierapravaj praz Lammier, jakaja dazvaliaje vandroŭnikam praciahnuć šliach na zachad u Russbach.

Chrobak - heta nievialikaja hramada ziemliarobaŭ, što liažyć u nizinnych zabahnienych miaścinach miž rekami Maćcid, Lammier i Avier. Naturaĺnaje abvadnieńnie, što zabiaśpiečvajecca rekami, zrabila hety kraj ideaĺnaj vornaj ziamlioju, a blizkija Francen i Avierchajm karystajucca ščodrymi dastaŭkami ziernia z vioski.

Russbach - heta viosačka, źmiescavanaja ŭ dziarnovych balotach da poŭdnia ad uzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhieĺ. Prosta pad pavierchniaj ziamli znachodziacca hlybokija hlinianyja karjery, i žychary Russbach zarabliajuć na žyćcio zdabyčaj budaŭničaha materyjalu. Vandroŭniki paznajuć, što jany znachodziacca niedalioka ad vioski, kali adčuvajuć zjedlivy pach dymu ad piečak muliaraŭ.

Cytadeĺ Chaĺštied znachodzicca na paŭdniova-ŭschodnim ŭskrajku ŭzhorkaŭ Šcirchuhieĺ i zjaŭliajecca pieravaĺnym punktam dlia Darožnych Nahliadnikaŭ kraja. Spačatku heta byŭ faĺvarak, jaki prynaliežaŭ niejkamu daŭno zabytamu šliachciču, z časam jon rabiŭsia ŭsio boliej i boliej umacavanym, bo kožny nastupny ŭlaśnik imknuŭsia abaranić jaje žycharoŭ ad bandytaŭ i zielienaskurych z susiedniaha Liesu Aĺtern. Urešcie jon pierajšoŭ u ruki haspadarstva i byŭ aficyjna pieraŭtvorany ŭ krepasć-načlieh dlia Darožnych Nahliadnikaŭ, jaki achoŭvajuć miascovasć.

Raab - heta vioska, jakaja naturaĺnaj čynam utvarylasia vakol Śviacilišča Šaĺli. Źmiescavanaja na źlićci šmatlikich šliachoŭ, jana byla naturaĺnym miescam dlia prydarožnaha śviacilišča - miesca, dzie padarožniki mahli spynicca, adpačyć i paprasić dabraslavieńni na svoj šliach. Adnojčy handliar vinom, jaki časta naviedvaŭ śviacilišča, zrazumieŭ kaštoŭnasć hetkaha zručnaha zvyčaju i pabudavaŭ na skryžavańni karčmu. Nieŭzabavie vakol jaje ŭtvarylasia hramada, i paŭstala vioska Raab.

Tennek - vioska vinarobaŭ, jakija zabiaśpiečvajuć miascovy aporny punkt Darožnych Nahliadnikaŭ u Cytadeli Chaĺštied. Tennek utvaryŭsia z siemjaŭ abaviaźnikaŭ, jakija klapacilisia pra tutejšuju ziamliu i šliachtu z faĺvarku Chaĺštied. Kali faĺvarak Chaĺštied pieratvaryŭsia ŭ Cytadeĺ Chaĺštied, jany stali voĺnymi liudźmi i vyrašyli apracoŭvać svaje ziemli dlia prodažu sadaviny i napojaŭ. Darožnyja Nahliadniki z Cytadeli Chaĺštied časta prymajuć niekaĺki halonaŭ vina ŭ miesiac u pamien na zabieśpiačeńnie biaśpieki žycharoŭ Tenneka.

Švarchafien - nievialikaja vioska, cikavaja svajoj historyjaj. Amaĺ piaćsot hadoŭ tamu tut adbylasia vialikaja bitva, i ruiny zamka i staraja vioska na ŭschodzie ad sielišča, mierkavana, usio, što fizična zastalosia ad taho kanfliktu. Sučasnaja vioska kvitnieje, alie naściarožana stavicca da čužyncaŭ z-za svajho stanovišča lia Siĺvanii.

Naŭbonum - nievialikaja vioska na miažy Siĺvanii. Liudzi tut žyvuć haloŭnym čynam za košt hadoŭli zbožžavych kuĺtur, kab pracharčavać siabie, a ŭsie inšyja tavary nabyvajucca za košt prodažu liškaŭ uradžaju ci pracy. Bo vioska znachodzicca lia Pryvidnyja Ŭzhorki, žychary časta turbujucca pra čužyncaŭ z uschodu, pryvidaŭ i niačyścikaŭ. Paliavyja Nahliadniki paŭroślikaŭ, viadoma, čas ad času spyniajucca ŭ sieliščy i patruliujuć ŭschodnija miežy Muuta.

Malieńki haradok Biularchof niadaŭna viarnuŭsia ŭ lona śviatych, skinuŭšy svaich siĺvanski valadaroŭ. Kuĺt Biuloraka, boha zachodnich haradskich bahnaŭ, zjaŭliajecca pieravažnaj vieraj žycharoŭ. Śviatary Biuloraka ŭziali na siabie kiravańnie horadam i jaho spravami, imknučysia da boĺšaj padtrymki i reintehracyi z Šcirliandam. Horad maje čatyry nievialikija chramy, pryśviečanyja Biuloraku, Morru, Zihmaru i Šaĺli adpaviedna. Na zachadzie ad horada, pobač z Biularchofskimi Bahnami, liažyć u ruinach stary zamak šliachcičaŭ.

Štiernist - kvitniejučaja liasnaja vioska, jakaja staić miž Halodnym Liesam i Svarzijaj. Viaskovyja zarabliajuć boĺšuju častku svajho bahaćcia na vysiečcy miascovaha liesu i splavie jaho pa Ešenšciru da Zihfrydofa na kirmaš. Liudzi tut vieĺmi addanyja Moru, časta zaklikajuć Krumkačych Rycaraŭ baranić ich ad Hoblinaŭ i inšych niebiaśpiekaŭ navakoĺnych liasoŭ ci pahroz, što zychodziać zdalioku.

Fierštajn - malieńkaja vioska, źmiescavanaja na paŭdniovym boku bahnistaha Morfiena, u basiejnie Ešenšcira. Tutejšyja vieĺmi izaliavany ad navakoĺnaha śvietu, uzajemadziejničajuć ź Impieryjaj toĺki padčas svaich padarožžaŭ u Zihfrydchof, dlia prodažu sušanaj ryby. Fierštajny taksama viadomy jak vydatnyja stralki, jakija časta služać lučnikami ci vyviednikami ŭ Krumkačych Rycaraŭ.

Kaŭnic - heta nievialikaja viosačka na krajnim poŭdni Šcirlianda. Liudzi tut zarabliajuć na žyćcio ŭ asnoŭnym apracoŭkaj uzhorystych ziemliaŭ, što atačajuć ich horad, a taksama zdabyčaj rudy z ziamli. Boĺšasć padarožnikaŭ i ich tavaraŭ vitajucca ŭ Kaŭnicy, a Hnomy časta prajazdžajuć tut padčas svaich padarožžaŭ za miežy horaŭ ŭ šyrejšuju Impieryju. Adnak liudzi naściarožana staviacca da mudrahielistych liudziej i biez vahańniaŭ prahaniajuć lahiery Stryhanaŭ ci inšaje padobnaje śmiećcie sa svajoj chaty.

Marburh - malieńkaja viosačka na šliachu miž Vurtbadam i Zihfrajdchofam. Vioska viadoma svaimi śvińniami i ŭradžajami, jakija mohuć dapamahčy pracharčavać šmatlikija blizkija hramady i harady paślia dobraha ŭradžaju. Na žaĺ, blizkasć vioski da Vialikaha Liesu aznačaje častyja ŭvarvańni jaho nasieĺnikaŭ i, adpaviedna, nižejšyja ŭradžai.

Zihmarynhien - pieršy z siami chramaŭ Zihmara, jaki idzie pa zychodnamu šliachu, što prajšoŭ pieršy impieratar u čornyja hory, kab zabić Šaranoraka, pieršanarodžanaha Drakonavaha Ohra. Tutejšyja žychary zarabliajuć boĺšuju častku svaich hrošaŭ, prymajučy pilihrymaŭ i zabiaśpiečvajučy ich ježaj i ryštunkam dlia pachodu ŭ hory.

Viordarn is a small town hidden between mountains and valleys. The rough terrain makes expansion near impossible, but the intersection of the Stary Šliach Hnomaŭ and the Prager strasse makes passing along viable; not that it matters, as no outsider finds kindness in Viorden. The odd muutliandy can occasionally be seen purchasing supplies for the road, but its main attraction is the Viorden Meat and Cattle auction house. Its the only town in Šcirliand that can be smelled before it is seen.

Kieĺchem is isolated among the hills of the Stary Šliach Hnomaŭ. Its secluded location allows the inhabitants to peacefully farm wheat and other cereals. Its golden fields go just about the start of Lies Aĺtern, where the fertility of the land drops inexplicably. Whatever is not used for local consumption is sent out along the Muut Road to the rest of eastern Šcirliand and, ultimately, the Muutliand.

Marbierh Castle lies to the south of Mittlienburh near the pilgrim trail leading to the seven temples of Šaranorak. The castle was erected to safeguard the passes leading out of the Hory Rohu Śvietu for Dwarf traders as well as to watch over the territory north of the Black Fire Pass.
Hipfeĺ, A small village in the heart of the Greenleaf Hills.

The town of Drakienchof was once considered a beacon of culture within the Empire. But after the sinister takeover of Siĺvanija by the Vampire Counts, the formerly tall and inspiring spires of Castle Drakienchof now loom menacingly over the townspeople of Drakienchof. The people of Drakienchof are oppressed under the thumb of the fon Carstein lineage. They use the town of Drakienchof to hide their dangerous and other worldly possessions. The people exist as snacks for passing vampires. And every dark corner is the lair for myraid and unspeakable evils. Praying on the townsfolk from dusk till dawn.

Nachthafien is a very uninteresting place. Which is just as its ruler Hrafinia Gabriella fon Bundebad prefers. Nachthafien does not get involved in the petty squabbles of vampiric intrigue. Nor does it seek war with the Empire. It exists purely as a quiet, normal village. With nothing to see here. Just tasty villagers minding their business until it is time for the masters to feed.

Foĺburh was the site of a minor rebellion by mortal villagers against their vampiric overlord. Despite gruesomely ripping apart Hraf Aduhl fon Kohnfried with his dying breath he left a curse. The flesh of the villagers began slowly rotting away. But their lives would not leave this mortal coil. The villagers found themselves eternal slaves to a dead master. Now they are maddened skeletons roaming their old dwellings. Pretending to a cheap parody of life. And you better not remind them of what they are.

Hierchof does not sleep. Its paranoid vampire Hraf Johan fon Goal has forbidden it. A trickster Crone allegedly put a curse on the count. But none other than the Hraf himself can verify this. It has been said that a sleeping mortal would slay fon Goal in a brutal fashion. So fon Goal banned sleep. The mortal citizens are skittish. Sneaking an hour or twos nap in the dark corners of the city. Ordered to be ever watchful for the one who would slay their fearful ruler.

There are tales of Castle Templchof. At one point in history it was the home of the cruel Hrafinia Emanuelle fon Templchof. During a dark and terrible battle with the Hnomy besieging her home Hrafinia Emanuelle bathed her castle in profane magic. Causing an everlasting night to envelop the surrounding area. The indomitable Hnomy persisted however. Despite many losses they slew the wicked Hrafinia within Castle Templchof. Her anguished screams were said to echo throughout the halls long after the Hnomy left runes to repel dark magic. Recently, it has become known that some of those runes have faded. And dark things stir within the castle again. Lead by a chorus of screams.

The town of Templchof has seen many nightmarish things. Formerly under the auspices of the Vampire Hrafinia Emanuelle fon Templchof the village has recently become the home to a group of Light Mages. Whilst the townsfolk cling to these people as saviours they still whisper of a phantom. The tale of Whispering Nell is well known amongst the townsfolk. A foul spectre who haunts the town and surrounding area. Stealing children and killing Men. Almost as if she owns the place.

Vanchaĺdienchof is a miserable blot on the map of Siĺvanija. Originally constructed to guard the castle of Vanhaldenschlosse and its master, the Necromancer Frederick van Hal. After that castle fell into ruin the village remained as an area for the vampires of Siĺvanija to feed on its inhabitants and torment them. The villagers treated as little more than free roaming cattle.

Yet another blighted and miserable place. The villagers treated as little more than snacks from nearby fon Carsteins. Though rebellion has fermented in Mikaĺsdorf it has been put down so many times that the villagers are wretched, sad things. Shuffling around with no hope for any rescue.

Though unassuming at first, Chundam is a place of whispered rumours. It is said that the dead walk freely on its streets. As if mimicking the appearance of life. Others say puppets dance the night away, stringless and alive somehow. No one knows for sure for few have braved its narrow streets, its dusty shops, or its surprisingly open and inviting tavern. But all who go near have warned others to never approach Chundam in the night. For that is when bands of Vampires emerge to dance and make merry. And theyd just love to have a flushed and oh so juicy mortal to dance with.

Fort Vobierštar was once a small but mighty fortress of the Empire. Built shortly after the defeat of Vlad fon Carstein in the siege of Aĺtdorf during one of the great Vampire wars of 2010 IC. However, many centuries later after neglect and lack of manpower the fortress was easily taken by Konrad fon Carstein. Though the Empire reclaimed the fort it was taken again many years later by Mannfred fon Carstein. Who put a terrible curse on the fort. Whenever it is sieged the wrathful specters of past wars rise to kill any and all who threaten the fort. Those spirits lay claim to the fort. And the Empire has been unsuccessful at reclaiming it since.

The oddest thing about Murieste is that its people do not follow the religion of Zihmar. Nor any other state approved religion. In fact, the lowly villagers of Murieste worship the vampires around them as gods. Coverting their dark power and hoping to become one of their dark kin. The Vampires in the area tolerate this. Seeing the pathetic peasants as amusing cattle. Vampires do love to play with their food.

Known for being a favourite haunt of Vampires looking to drag their victims off for a good torture session, the screams heard from Fort Brachier can be heard for miles around. Brachier is often fought over by Vampire counts. All of them looking for a new lair from which to torment Men of the Empire.

Most Vampire Counts leave Štuudchof alone, It has been ruled efficiently as a slaughterhouse for human cattle by its ruler. From the outside it simply looks like another mud covered village in the middle of this desolate land. From which very little is known about.

Renowned for its tapestries made of human flesh. Nachtšloss is a place of wanton butchery and desolation. With darkness around every corner and in every hall of its cursed interior. Monsters freely roam the corridors. Looking for new victims to try their latest stitching patterns on.
Hallchof is often a favourite haunt of Brettonian Blood Knights. Used as a training camp and feasting hall for these bloodthirsty creatures.

Zenkchof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Zenkchof and its surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Zenkchof is one of the last bastions of free humans in Sylvannia. Despite officially being under the dominion of the Vampire Counts, human adventurers and crusaders often use Zenkchof and its surrounding town to stage conflicts against their vampiric masters. Or at least as a base from which to look for treasure.

Mere months before the Vampire wars. A sorcerer of Nurgle cursed the surrounding village with a plague. The nobility of Vartenchof barricaded themselves in the castle. The villagers begged for salvation as their flesh swelled and burst from deadly boils. But the nobility cared little for them. Inside the castle, the nobles slowly went insane. Becoming cultists of Nurgle within their isolated walls. They were slain by the Vampires as they took over Sylvannia. But the scars of Nurgles rot still remain.

As the nobles of Vartenchof locked themselves away, the blighted souls of Vartenchof village slowly succumbed to the sickness of Nurgles Rot. Many simply died. They were lucky. For Nurgle sees his sickness as a blessing and gift. And one must be alive to experience it all. When the Vampire Counts came for Vartenchof, the few villages left gladly bound themselves to vampiric service in exchange for a cure. As their service wavers the rot returns. So the Villagers do their best to remain loyal.

This swampy village is isolated from most of Sylvannia. Crossable only by boat, the houses are on stilts and it is very hard for any vampire to find purchase within Sumpdorf. The villagers and farmers know they are safe from the zombies that haunt the Dark Moor. But the local Vampire Counts still come by air from Vartenchof Castle to collect the blood tax.

Hryśsienvaĺd is the northernmost settlement in Vissenliand, right along the banks of the Rajk. South of the beginning of the Vorbergland Canal System as well as the southern extent of the Rajkvaĺd forest. The Dwarf Shanty, ‘Kazid Slumbol sits against the south side of its palisade, and is mostly home to transient Dwarf traders and caravanners, resting here with their more permanent kin before continuing on their routes. Many hunters, trappers and woodcutters make their residence here and during the day will go north into the Rajkvaĺd to make their living. The Southern Rajkvaĺd is known for being particularly infested with monsters and neer do wells. As a result the ruler of Hryśsienvaĺd, Hraf Bruno Pfeifraucher, is a professional military man who is often seen leading a patrol around his town to keep the forests dangers at bay.

Rochrhaŭzen is an isolated Visenliander village known for its excellent vineyards, popular even in some of the best taverns in Nuĺn. This is in part thanks to the cool waters of the River Griss, which come out of the mountains near Rochrhaŭzen.

Viśsienburh is the capital of Vissenliand and, while it might not carry the economic or cultural weight of Nuĺn, it is truly the centre of the people. The folk here are the epitome of those virtues which makes Visenlianders unique from the rest of the Empire. The boughers, artisans and labourers go about their business with thrift and daur pragmatism, speaking clearly and in short direct sentences. Unlike in Aĺtdorf or Nuĺn, the people here have no time for poetic or flowery expressions. Most of the citizens work the various temples in the city into their daily routine, picking one each day and paying their respect if only for a few minutes, allowing them to pay respect to most of the principal gods each week. Viśsienburh is also the last stop for river trade on the upper Rajk before Nuĺn and is surrounded by good farmland. Elector-Hrafinia Emmanuelle fon Liebwitz seldom journeys to Viśsienburh, coming only to meet the ‘po-faced boughers which sit on the Assembly of Vissenliand. As a result, while the town is ruled in her name, Baranesa Toppenheimer has been given more and more control over the province as a whole.

On the Border of the Grey Mountains, along the shores of the River Wissen is the village of Dotternbach. The Visenlianders here are shepherds used to climbing high into the lands west of their homes, and as such make strong recruits when they have the young men to spare.
Chaĺhierbach is an isolated Visenliander village right on the traditional border with Old Zoĺliand. It sits on the shores of the River Wissen, which the people here use to irrigate their crops.
On the western shore of the River Soll, at one of the only nearby ferries across the river, is the village of Durbchajm. The Sollanders here tend sheep to provide wool to nearby Fajĺdorf.

Biernaŭ is your typical Sollander village; the people here are mostly shepherds who raise sheep for their wool. They sell this wool at nearby Fajĺdorf for a decent price and are happy with their modest living.

On the eastern shore of the River Soll is the Sollander village of Zeksaŭ. The people here are not very well off, and typically can only grow enough food to feed themselves. What extra they do produce is taken to market at Fajĺdorf.

Across the River Soll from Krojtcchafien is the small village of Vajlierbierh. The closeness of the two communities results in a great many ties between them. For instance the town grave digger for Krojtcchafien, Boris Hippler, makes his residence here in Vajlierbierh.

The Sollanders of Zerryh are simple people and are proud of it. Asking any of the shepherds here if they have any greater aspirations than sheep will elicit a round of laughter followed by the statement that: ‘my family has been here since the fall of Zoĺliand, not even a Daemon could make me abandon our trade!

Avinhien is a small Visenliander farming community on the shore of the lower River Soll, just south of a small marshy confluence caused by the lower Soll meeting with the Soll. The people here sell much of their grain to nearby Karak Norn in return for coin and drink, though they will sell you what grain they have to spare.

Chajzienbierh is well renowned for its deep red wines, which are shipped and sold from Fajĺdorf to Kislev. The Visenliander winemakers here credit the upper River Soll for irrigating their land, as well as the fair winds out of the Granite pass, for the quality of their fruit.

Along the shore of the lower River Soll is the village of Aŭhien. At one time this land would have been populated by Sollanders, but today this part of Sudenland is home to Visenlianders. The people here can trace their roots back at least three centuries and are very experienced farmers. Aŭhien is well used by passersby, as the village sits on the Granite Pass road, the main route between Majssen and Karak Norn.
Kieĺhard is a small Visenliander village on the western shore of the upper Soll. The people here mostly mine the nearby mountains for Iron ore.

To the north of Hiešburh is Fliurn, an old Sollander village that has been on the maps since before the fall of Zoĺliand. The people here carry on the traditions of Zoĺliand, and even have a small shrine to Myrmidia.

To the south of Hiešburh is Aĺtchaŭzen, a Sollander village populated mostly by shepherds. The land here is also good for vineyards, and while the Aĺtchaŭzen vintage hasnt become renowned outside of the region, it is well received in Hiešburh.

Zochtenaŭ is a relatively new community, established within the last few generations as an attempt by the people of Zoĺliand to restore some of their former glory. Like many Sollanders, they seem to carry the weight of their past on their backs and in their bones, but they take pride in their work and look after their sheep with thrift and efficiency.

Štajnhart was once a moderately sized city. With the destruction of old Zoĺliand, what remains of Štajnhart today is but a husk of what used to be. Around the present day town can be found the eight hundred year old ruins. In Štajnhart, the oppressive air that hangs around the Sollanders is the heaviest, as if theyd be happier if they could just forget their former grandeur. To the south of Štajnhart is a set of ancient standing stones, commonly called ‘Taĺs Fangs. This name is in spite of the insistence of the cult of Taaĺ that the site is not Taĺite in origin. A ferry across the River Oggel is here, in the direction of Miendieĺchof.
Near Waldbach is the small Visenliander settlement of Moasach. The people of Moasach provide for themselves by raising pigs.

Within sight of the wall in Ahbajtien is the Visenliander village of Balienchof. The people here are friendly, but have a deep mistrust of Averlianders, saying: ‘they refuse to evr sign a contract, take me at my word they say, on their ‘oner they say. I tell em if Im to take em on their ‘oner, then I need the Crowns and Shillings now!

Irrigated by the River Soll, the Sollanders here at Ajhienchof are able to grow a large quantity of grain and other foodstuffs, which they often take to Wursterburg to be loaded onto a ship and sold farther north.
Nestled in the hills to the northwest of Vusterburh is the Sollander village of Rötenbach. The people here are mostly shepherds, and have been known to range their sheep as far as Zerryh.
Zaĺmfahr is a small Visenliander farming community along the shores of the upper River Soll. It is protected from danger by nearby Nihren.
Truĺbien is a small Sollander village that primarily gets by through the wool trade. The shepherds here often work with the shepherds of Rotienbach and Zerryh.

Near the mountainous source of the River Sonne is the village of Šarmbiek. The people here are hardy mountain dwelling Sollanders, who make their living either by working in the mine at nearby Tierhügel or by raising cattle in the small plain to the northwest of the settlement. On the rise just north of the village centre is a ring of ancient standing stones.
On the Zonnfurt-Wursterburg road is the village of Taĺfanh, which cuts timber and entertains passerbys.

Mierfieĺd is a village in the Vohieliand and as a result is part of the land held in dispute between Averliand and Vissenliand. To the north of Mierfieĺd is the bridge over the upper Rajk to Hocheleben, to the south is the village of Jenhien.

Jenhien is a small community in the Vohieliand that in recent years has found itself in the middle of a dispute between Vissenliand and Averliand. By an ancient treaty the division between Vissenliand and Averliand is set south of the upper River Rajk and fifty leagues east of the River Oggel. Unfortunately, the upper Rajk is known to change its course regularly and leagues are no longer used in the Empire in favour of the Imperial Mile. The fertile, well watered grasslands of the Oggeland is greatly desired by both the Vissenliand Sheep Herders, and the Averliand Cattle Ranchers; brawls or even ‘battles have been known to commence between the two groups. Rancher and Herder alike have petitioned their lords to settle this dispute, with the sword if need be.

Vostercieĺ is formerly recognized as part of Vissenliand, the fort at Miendieĺchof is there to insure this. Despite these legal realities, the people of Vostercieĺ have always maintained a greater kinship with Averlianders than they have with Visenlianders or even Sollanders. Should Averliand choose to act on the Vohieliand dispute, the people of Vostercieĺ would support them.
Paĺ is a Sollander village. The people here are mostly shepherds and rely on the production of wool to make ends meet.

Travellers heading by the Icy Wind Pass to or from Karak Hirn inevitably pass through Kroppienlibien. Many choose to stop here and spend the night before continuing their journey. The small community of Kroppienlibien has no qualms with providing these travellers with shelter, or selling them the furs that local hunters have collected this season. Kroppienlibien is on the shores of the River Hornberg, just after the River Aulen has contributed to its flow.
Bidernaŭ is a Sollander village just north across the Soll from Vusterburh. The people here produce just enough food to feed themselves, taking what little they have to spare to market at Vusterburh.
Forcen is a small community of Visenliander foresters, who provide wood for many of the nearby settlements.
Maŭchien is a small community of Visenliander foresters, they are known particularly well in Vupiertaĺ, where most of their wood is shipped across the Rajk for cutting.
On the road to Štajh and Viśsienburh from Erbšaŭen is the small fishing village of Eĺvanhien, whose name comes from an ancient legal requirement for road construction.

A run-down pest hole inhabited by the poorest of the poor, alcoholism and crime are rampant here. The population has around 1200 kislevite immigrants who live in their own slice of heaven called little kislev. The kislevites and the local talabeclanders dont really interact much.

Upstream of the river Uckro, The villagers of Tojpic are a tight knit community, where everyone adds to the needs of each other. They dont get many visitors and those that do visit often come to trade for wood from the local lumber mill.

Close to the treeline of the forest that touches Talabchajms crater wall. The villagers of Dreec keep cows, many shepherds and some veterinarians take care of the great herd of cattle that graze in and around the fields of Dreec.

Near the mouth of the river Lochra, hence the name, the villagers of Lochrafurt are farmers and pig herders. Water is often carried through the village from the river to provide for the fields and the many pigs that bathe in the mud pits around the village.

A fishing village that borders the river Talabec. Vienau is surrounded by tents that bear the colours of Ostland. However the village of Vienau doesnt give the ostlanders the treatment that Biek gives them. Even though they outnumber the locals, the village elder has put the immigrants to work, either aiding in the fishing, forming hunter groups, with the local śviatars blessing of course, or farmers.
A small village with a stretch of the Vialiki Lies to the east and a few hills to the south. Its villagers are mainly woodcutters and eke out a decent existence trading said timber.

Bordering the river Lochra on two sides, Ertburh enjoys the natural protection the river offers from the west and the south. Ertburh is a diverse village, with some hunters, some farmers, some fishermen and a few śviatary who tend to a small chapel of Taaĺ.

A bustling town along the river Šcir and the river kölpin with many of the local populace consisting of woodcutters. Theres alot of taverns for the woodcutters to take a load off after work and all of them are named after the job their patrons have. They have Mourners guild, which is dedicated to the Cult of Morr, and is responsible for organising funerals and seeing to the upkeep of the local graveyard.

An unassuming farming village east of the river kölpin, no road leads to Sabritz, instead farmers follow the river south to reach Hiersdorch. They dont care much about this, for they prefer solitude and are quite suspicious of strangers.

Separated from the Barren Hills by a stretch of the Vialiki Lies, Pryštlichajm is home to a large Zihmarite monastery, the Temple of Leopold “the Hammer of Faith.” The brothers here are dedicated to the study and eventual eradication of whatever curses the Barren Hills. Although they will explore the hills themselves, they also hire adventurers if other matters demand their attention. The monastery also hunts down any Mutants that wander north out of the hills.

Harndorf is a fortified village with its back to the river Talabec and one side bordering the River Karwe. Harndorf enjoys its natural protection, its land borders protected by a stone wall, Harndorf has a solid strategic position. One can enter Harndorf through a portcullis in the wall or through a ferry across the river Talabec.

The southernmost village of Voĺhien. Its villagers maintain a big herd of sheep that graze near the barren hills. Despite Pryštlichajms efforts to stop the supposed hauntings from the barren hills, the odd sheep still goes missing now and again. Despite this the herd remains quite large.

Bordering the river Šcir and being at the centre of a crossroads, Missen sees alot of traffic from the surrounding villages. Missen has bits of forest a few ways away and the local populace earns a decent living trading timber.
A community of tree lovers as theyre often described, they give praise to Taaĺ and only use the wood of dead trees, they get by on their meagre farms and foraging in the Vialiki Lies.

A long way from other towns and villages the village of Aśsino is quite poor, despite its decent food stocks. It sees a decent amount of traffic from anyone that comes and goes from Ostermark and sometimes people that travel down the river Šcir, but not many wish to stay long in such a desolate looking place. Many requests have been sent to Hiermsdorf for tools and supplies to fix the village but not much has been set in motion as of yet.

A village close to a small bit of forest and surrounded by small hills. The villagers of Badaŭ have many farms close to the base of the hills to utilize rainwater flowing down the hills for irrigation.

Bordering a great swathe of the Vialiki Lies the villagers of Chorna are mainly hunters and woodsmen. Chorna earns a decent amount of money from the meat and hides they sell and give praise to Taaĺ for it.
Slightly wealthier in terms of food and coin than most villages in Talabecland. Kliepcyh enjoys the protection Castle Ravienštajn provides.

Tucked in between two parts of the Vialiki Lies, Zuryn houses a decent amount of Taaĺ worshippers, often going on pilgrimage to Talabchajm or answering Taĺs call. The Fishermen of Zuryn often walk north towards the river Uckro to fish, enjoying the walk in the Vialiki Lies as they do so. Those that remain keep themselves busy with the worship of Taaĺ and tending the farms.

Frederchajm is a small Rajkliander village just north of Aĺtdorf on the Aĺtdorf-Midienchajm road. While the town is a possession of Karl-Franz and is a part of Aĺtdorfs demesne, the Emperor has seen fit to give oversight of it in all but name to the Cult of Šaĺlia. This is a result of the cults request for an area in which to establish a walled hospice and sanatorium.

On the eastern side of the confluence of the rivers Taaĺ and Rajk sits the village of Kaĺdach. The town is notable particularly for being the demarcation of the Rajkliand/Talabecland border. Besides this, it remains a small farming community.

Directly west of Aĺtdorf, between the river Rajk and the Vajssbruk canal is the village of Hochlof. The town is known for the type of grain it raises the Hochloffkorn which is very well regarded for making a high quality flour.

Choĺthuzen is a town in western Rajkliand on the river Schilder. By road it lies between Ajĺchart and Šyĺdierchajm. The towns primary trade good is the Choĺthuzen Hogshead barrel which is used across the empire to age or ferment their products before shipment. The barrels are said to be so sturdy as to be able to protect their contents even from direct cannon fire. Every year Choĺthuzen hosts the Weinfest, a great gathering for wine tasting that requires an invite to enter. Of course the lack of invite does not stop the horde of wastrels and rogues who wish to drink the free wine provided by the festival. Weinfest also marks the only time of year during which the Golden Cask is brought out, which is said to contain the best wine in the Empire if not the entire Old World. Due to the towns forested location, it is frequently attacked by beastmen. The palisades and guards are normally strong enough to see the monsters off, but the townspeople fear the day this defence falls short. As such, some of the townspeople have been leaving casks of cheap wine at the edge of the woods in an attempt to appease the beastmen with tribute. This dubious practice likely will not be allowed to continue much longer.

Ajĺchart remains its mark on the map for one reason; the popularity of its vintage of white wine. Ajĺchart wine is one of the Rajkliands best wines, valued for its crisp light flavours and its mild hangovers. Ajĺchart is a destination for riverboat cruises, where wealthy merchants and nobles from Aĺtdorf often come up the river to taste the various local vintages and foods. Many of the people here are said to have bretonnian heritage, visitors often comment on the similar bone structure shared by many of the inhabitants.

Uśsinhien is a small village located on the road between Choĺthuzen and Vośburh. The town is at the furthest point that the River Schilder remains navigable by barge, meaning that many shipments bound for Chieĺmhart will arrive first here. The people here raise crops along the river Schilder and will venture into the nearby Grey Mountains to mine seams of ore. The town is well protected by the walls at Chieĺmhart, and really only worries about the denizens of the Rajkvaĺd.

Morlienfurt is a small village near the headwaters of the river Bogen. The town is known for its silver mines and the small community of Hnomy which contribute to the silver trade within the Rajkliand.

At the foot of the Axe Bite Pass sits the village of Vośburh, the last Imperial settlement before the Market fortress of Chieĺmhart and the Imperial/Bretonnian border. Any shipments bound for Chieĺmhart must pass first through Vośburh, and this source of trade makes the merchants here fairly prosperous.

To the north northwest of Biohienchafien is the timber producing village of Chiercchaĺd. Situated deep in the Rajkvaĺd, Chiercchaĺd is known for the quality and lengths of its timber samples, much of which is sent to Biohienchafien and Hriunburh for their boatbuilding.

Hrajssbach is a forest village just north of Ubieršrajk. The people here carefully timber the woods nearby and grow what crops they can in the clearings around the village. For a long time there have been rumors and worries about a dark estate just east of the village, which is said to house great evil.

To the south of Ubieršrajk is the mining town of Chuhieĺdaĺ. Chuhieĺdaĺ was founded three hundred years after the founding of the empire to mine copper and iron from the Grey mountains. In 1112 IC, town records indicate that the Black Plague devastated the local population and nearly ruined the town. The cult of Šaĺlia saw fit to establish a hospice here shortly thereafter. Not long after the arrival of the Šaĺlians, the Stryhany that have always frequented the area were banned from entering the town. Despite this they regularly pitch camp outside of the palisade to entertain and trade with the locals
Barfschajm is a small village along the river Hryśsien near the Hrafinia Emmanuelle canal. Its grain often is exported out of the Rajkliand to feed Hryśsienvaĺd and Nuĺn.

Štajndorf is a small village near the headwaters of the river Hryśsien. Its people refuse to travel into the Grey Mountains that often overshadow the village. Despite the fact that the minerals would bring great wealth to the village, the people here speak of a dread castle in the mountains above them, saying that they would rather remain in their vale with their grain.

Naffdorf is an isolated village that sits along the Grey Lady Canal between Šcimmihien and Chuhieĺdaĺ. Naffdorf is almost entirely surrounded by a marshland created by the nearby rivers Teufel, Ober and Tranig. In truth there is not much reason to stop in Naffdorf, the villages main commodity is the fish that use the canals to move between the rivers.

Tajfieĺfojer is a rural village outside of Kiempierbad. The village is truly only notable for being the scene where one hundred years ago the forces of the Rajkliand Clashed with one of the largest hordes of Beastmen to emerge from the Rajkvaĺd Forest. The story goes that when the battle wizards through their magical fire towards the monstrosities, the trees around them burst into a devils fire with hues not natural to this world. The people here are proud of this story and often hawk the ‘relics of this historic battle.

Dzisdorf is a small town on the river Rajk located between Aĺtdorf and Kiempierbad. Dzisdorf is a major holy site of the Cult of Zihmar, it is said that Magnus the Pious once made a powerful and stirring speech to the crowds who had gathered to hear him. Around sixty years ago, Emperor Wilhelm III founded the Dzisdorf Military college to train those who have proven their leadership abilities in battle.

Liachienbad sits along the Tranig river at the joining points of the Grey Lady and Ober-Šcimmihien canals. While the village is a farming community, it is the home of a talented blacksmith, Uli and his promisingly talented son Valten.

Vorlic is a river village protected by the forces garrisoning the Zamak Rajkshard. The people here are very loyal directly to the Emperor Karl-Franz who many believe to be a reincarnation of Zihmar. The town benefits from trade heading down the Rajk to Aĺtdorf, Maryjenburh and beyond.

The town of Hriunburh sits on the river Teufel. While trade flows through the town from the canals to itself and from the Rajk to its north, Hriunburhs main source of wealth comes from its river boatyards, where many of the boats and barges that ply the rivers of the Rajkliand originate from. The town is also famous for the Battle of Hriunburh where the advance of Orc Warlord Gorbad Ironclaw was finally halted around a half a millenia ago. The battle plains is valued particularly due to the fact that nearly all of the Imperial and orc forces present were mounted calvarymen, unusual for both the contemporary period and the modern era. As such an excavation site has been established by several interested parties and many come to look upon their work.

Vajssbruk sits on the joining of the Vajssbruk Canal and the river Bӧgen. The town once was a major source of coal and iron in the Rajkliand, the mining of which provided the Gruber family with enough funds to construct the Vajssbruk Canal, which enabled easier transportation of the mined material to market. Now the mines have mostly been depleted and while the town continues to have prosperous ventures in trade thanks to the canal, the many former workers of the mine have found themselves unemployed and stuck in Vajssbruk, where they spend their time drinking cheap alcohol and causing trouble.
Just to the south west of Aĺtdorf is the small village of Chajlihien. The village is nothing to speak of, but it is near the amber hills, which offer a spectacular view of Aĺtdorf from their height.

Rajnsfieĺd is a village along the Uhl river in the northwestern Rajkvaĺd. The people here are fairly isolated from the rest of the Province, relying on what little trade passes by on the road towards Maryjenburh.
